Award.AwardTitle: Linear and nonlinear geometric evolution equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Differential geometry studies the topological, geometric and analytic properties of the spaces. Since all physical events take places in a space, by Einstein's relativity the spatial metric properties of the underlying space have fundamental impacts on the physical events happening in the space, including the very one we live in. This relation places the subject of the differential geometry in a central position of the mathematics and some fundamental issues of sciences. Modern differential geometry appeals to the theory/methods of linear and nonlinear partial differential equations. The proposal involves the study of differential geometry via the method of the evolutional partial differential equations with the focus on the study of the entropy, the monotonicity, and related sharp differential estimates motives by thermodynamics and statistical mechanics. The study of Gauss curvature flow has important consequences on the subjects of the image processing, affine differential geometry and convex geometry. The study of the Ricci flow in the proposal advances the understanding of the differential topological structure of the spaces and is related to the theoretic physics with direct bearing on the high energy physics. The resolving of the problems involved in the proposal advances the above mentioned related subjects in sciences. The out-reach components of the proposal disseminate the new results to general public and contributes towards the mathematical education in the community in the greater area of San Diego and beyond. It also contributes to the training and the early career development of under-represented groups.


The technical aspects of the proposal involve the development of the sharp monotonicity of the entropy and related sharp point wise estimates. The study of differential geometric problems relies on solving evolution equations such as the Ricci flow equation, Gauss curvature flow equation or other nonlinear evolution equations, and/or the study of delicate properties of the solutions obtained. The theory of modern partial differential equations reduces the study of the solutions of various linear and nonlinear equations to the monotonicity of certain entropic quantities and related point wise estimates. The de-regularizing estimates proposed in this proposal broadens the scope of the already far-reaching gradient estimates, Hessian estimates and curvature estimates techniques developed in the last several decades to more general settings, by requiring less regularity of the solutions involved, while encoding far more geometric information. They have produced and will produce much powerful geometric consequences. The techniques developed can in turn advances the study of the related partial differential equations, which usually occupies a central role in the theory of the partial differential equations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Differential geometry studies the topological, analytical, metrical properties of spaces. The study is crucial to understand every event happening in the spaces. Curvature is a local invariant which measures the impact of mass in a space. A good example of such is Einstein's theory of general relativity.  Geometric flows uses the evolution equations such as Ricci flow, Gauss curvature flow to study the spatial properties of underlying manifolds. In this project the PI (with some of them are joint work with mathematician worldwide)  established two convergence results for flows by the Gauss curvature, and by the power of the Gauss curvature. These flow are used in models of various applied science including image processing. The successful study is built upon a discovery involving entropy and its monotonicity along the flow. As in other nonlinear PDEs, Gauss curvature flow is a parabolic Monge-Ampere equation, whose study requires the establishment of various a priori estimates. The most important one is the so-call $C^0$-estimates, namely the maximum of the absolute value of the solution involved. One example of such is S.-T. Yau's solution of the celebrated Calabi conjecture in 1970s,  where Yau used the Moser's iteration (a technique developed by J. Moser)  to obtain this. Here the situation is  more tricky. We estimate the $C^0$-estimate by the entropy estimate (which is an integral one), a non-collapsing estimate (namely geometric estimates involving various geometric invariants of the evolving convex body ,  based on entropy bounds) , a stability result and a compactness argument. This conceptually involved approach does not provide any effective estimate as what the robust Moser iteration delivers, but enough to prove the wanted $C^0$-estimate. Built upon this and the lower curvature estimate PI obtained the smooth convergence to a soliton (a selfsimilar state) result for such flows.  This work directly leads to the later development by Brendle-Choi-Daskalouplos on the classification of solitons. 

The PI also complete a classification of the shrinking solitons  for Ricci flow in dimension four. Another PI's work provides a PDE (partial differential equation) approach to the isoperimetric inequalities. This includes the famous result of Gromov and its generalization by Berard-Besson-Gallot.

More recently PI initiated the study of complex Kaehler manifolds with positive orthogonal Ricci curvature. Comparison and vanishing results have been proved for this new curvature. At the mean time PI also introduced and studied the $k$-scalar curvature, $k$-Ricci curvature. Projectivity of manifolds with positive second scalar curvature was proved by the PI. Since any Riemann surface is projective while most tori are not, this result is expected to be a sharp metric/intrinsic  criterion for the projecitvity. The $k$-hyperbolicity was introduced and proved for any compact Kaehler manifolds with  negative $k$-Ricci curvature. Since complex Kaehler manifolds are important  components in the string theory, the results are important in the study of physics.

  The PI also produces three sets of lecture notes (a course on Ricci flow, a course on geometric analysis and a course on Riemannian geometry. He also delivered many lectures worldwide, including two summer  minicourses. 

The PI is also actively involved in K-12 mathematical education. He teaches at local mathcircle and publishes article on American Mathematical Monthly,the most read mathematical journal with audiences of college students, professors as well as high school teachers. The PI also organized several local an dinternational conferences which provide platforms for the dissemination of the most recent development of the subject. 

The PI also provides mathematical consultation to medical scientists on possible models for the understanding of the development and the cure of the liver cancer.  PI's techniques in the study of the Monge-Ampere type equations can be applied to fields such as information geometry to deepen the current understanding of the information theory.
